text: Tyler Daschier Herron (born August 5, 1986) is a right-handed professional baseball pitcher for the Sioux Falls Canaries of the American Association of Independent Professional Baseball. As a senior at Wellington High School in Florida, Herron led the nation with a 0.25 ERA. He was drafted by the St. Louis Cardinals in the First Round of the 2005 Major League Baseball Draft. Herron was ranked the Midwest League # 11 prospect in 2007, and the St. Louis Cardinals # 10 prospect, by Baseball America. He pitched for the Honolulu Sharks in the Rookie 2008 Hawaii Winter Baseball League, and led the league with a 0.69 ERA. Pitching for the Indios de Mayagüez in the winter of 2014, he was a post-season Puerto Rico Liga de Béisbol Profesional Roberto Clemente All Star and a Caribbean World Series All Star. In 2016, pitching for the Fargo- Moorhead RedHawks, he led the independent American Association with a 0.80 ERA. Herron pitched for Team Israel at the 2017 World Baseball Classic. ==Early life== Herron was born and grew up in West Palm Beach, Florida."Tyler Herron Stats, Highlights, Bio", MiLB.com. – Healthy living from the ground up, Radish Magazine. He attended Wellington High School, in Wellington, Florida. Initially, in high school he played shortstop and third base. As a senior for the Wellington Wolverines, he led the nation with a 0.25 ERA, and struck out 81 batters in 57 innings."Wellington Adds To Its Elite," SunSentinel. ==Minor leagues== ===2005–2009=== Herron was drafted by the St. Louis Cardinals in the First Round (46th, overall) of the 2005 Major League Baseball Draft. His agent was Jim Munsey, his former T-ball pitcher. He received a $675,000 signing bonus."Tyler Herron Profile," Scout. He began his professional career in 2005 with the Johnson City Cardinals of the Rookie Appalachian League, going 0–3 in 13 starts with a 5.62 ERA and 49 strikeouts in 49.2 innings as he kept opponents to a .245 batting average."Cardinals Prospect #18 – Tyler Herron,", St. Louis – Scout. Herron was ranked the Appalachian League # 20 prospect, and the St. Louis Cardinals # 12 prospect, in 2005 by Baseball America."Stats: Tyler Herron", Baseball America. The following season, pitching for Johnson City, on August 13, 2006, Herron was voted Appalachian League Pitcher of the Week. In 13 starts for Johnson City he was 5–6 with a 4.13 ERA, and he lost his one start with the State College Spikes of the Class A-Short New York-Penn League while giving up two runs in six innings. He was ranked the Appalachian League # 13 prospect, and the St. Louis Cardinals # 18 prospect, in 2006 by Baseball America. Pitching for Johnson City and State College, he averaged 8.88 strikeouts per nine innings pitched, third-best among Cardinals' minor leaguers. In June 2007, pitching for the Class A Swing of the Quad Cities, he was named Cardinals Minor League Pitcher of the Month. On July 2, 2007, Herron was voted Midwest League Pitcher of the Week. For the season he was 10–7 with a 3.74 ERA, and in 137.1 innings gave up 26 walks while he had 130 strikeouts (6th in the league) as he kept opponents to a .240 batting average."2007 Midwest League – Season Review," Baseball Cube. He averaged 1.69 walks per nine innings as a starter, which was 4th-lowest among Midwest League starters, and his strikeout/walk ratio of 5.00 led the league. He threw primarily a mid-90s sinking fastball, a solid changeup, and a curveball with a good break."St. Louis Cardinals: Top 10 Prospects With Scouting Reports", Baseball America."Future Shock: Cardinals Top 11 Prospects," Baseball Prospectus. He was ranked the Midwest League # 11 prospect in 2007, and the St. Louis Cardinals # 10 prospect, by Baseball America. Pitching for the Class A-Advanced Palm Beach Cardinals, on August 4, 2008, Herron was voted Florida State League Pitcher of the Week. For the season for the team, he was 2–2 with a 2.70 ERA in 15 starts, and in 56.2 innings he gave up 11 walks as he kept opponents to a .234 batting average. Pitching for the Springfield Cardinals of the AA Texas League, he was 5–5 with a 5.20 ERA. He was ranked the St. Louis Cardinals # 23 prospect after the 2008 season by Baseball America. He pitched for the Honolulu Sharks in the Rookie 2008 Hawaii Winter Baseball League, and led the league with a 0.69 ERA."2008 Hawaii Winter Baseball Pitching Leaders," Baseball-Reference.com. Pitching for the Springfield Cardinals in 2009 he was 2–4 with a 4.34 ERA in 9 starts. Herron was released by the St. Louis Cardinals in June 2009. He was then signed that month by the Pittsburgh Pirates. Pitching the remainder of the season for the Altoona Curve of the AA Eastern League, he was 0–2 with a 4.50 ERA. He was released by the Pirates in October 2009. ===2010–present=== In 2010, Herron pitched for the Kalamazoo Kings in the independent Frontier League, primarily as a reliever, throwing between 89 and 93 mph with his fastball."NY Met's sign FM Redhawks pitcher Tyler Herron," KFGO-790."Nationals sign former first-round pick pitcher Tyler Herron," The Washington Post. He did not pitch in 2011 due to rehabilitation from surgery for an arm injury."RedHawks' Tyler Herron's contract sold to New York Mets," Valley News Live. In 2012, he pitched for the Fargo-Moorhead Redhawks of the independent American Association, going 12–3 with a 3.29 ERA (6th in the league) in 23 games (17 starts) over 123 innings with 105 strikeouts (6th in the league) and 30 walks. His 12 wins tied for second-best in the league, and his strikeouts/walks ratio of 3.50 was 7th-best in the league."2012 American Association – Season Review" In December 2012 the Washington Nationals signed Herron as a free agent to a minor league contract. In 2013, he pitched for the Potomac Nationals of the Class A-Advanced Carolina League, for whom he was 1–1 with a 1.70 ERA as he struck out 32 batters in 20.1 innings as he kept opponents to a .222 batting average, and the Harrisburg Senators of the AA Eastern League for whom he was 6–2 with a 3.11 ERA as he struck out 58 batters in 46.1 innings and kept opponents to a .247 batting average. Pitching for the Indios de Mayagüez in the winter of 2013, in the Puerto Rico Liga de Béisbol Profesional Roberto Clemente, in 19 games (third in the league) in relief Herron was 1–0 with a 0.84 ERA (leading the league, for all pitchers with 20 or more innings pitched)."Tyler Herron Minor, Winter & Independent Leagues Statistics & History" | Baseball- Reference.com"2013 Puerto Rican Winter League Pitching Leaders" | Baseball- Reference.com In 2014, Herron pitched for the Harrisburg Senators for whom he was 3–2 with a 2.73 ERA in 48 relief appearances (tied for 6th in the league), and for the Syracuse Chiefs of the AAA International League for whom he pitched 1.2 innings."2014 Eastern League – Season Review" Pitching for the Indios de Mayagüez in the winter of 2014, he was a post-season Puerto Rico Liga de Béisbol Profesional Roberto Clemente All Star. Pitching for Puerto Rico in 2014, Herron was a Caribbean World Series All Star."Es La Primera Vez Que México gana En Años Seguidos – México repite corona en la Serie del Caribe," Listín Diario. In 2015, Herron pitched for the Fargo-Moorhead RedHawks of the American Association, and was 6–7 with a 4.47 ERA in 20 starts, tied for second in the league with four complete games and two shutouts, and was third in the American Association with 119 strikeouts in 131 innings."FM Redhawks Re-Sign Tyler Herron" | Y94"2015 American Association – Season Review" Pitching for the Indios de Mayagüez in the Puerto Rico Liga de Béisbol Profesional Roberto Clemente in the winter of 2015, he was 5–2 with a 1.96 ERA in 18 relief appearances. In 2016, pitching for the Fargo-Moorhead RedHawks, he led the American Association with a 0.80 ERA in 56 innings in which he walked 12 batters, had a 5–1 record, and held opponents to a .161 batting average, at the time he was signed by the Mets."Mets Sign RHP Tyler Herron," MetsMinors.net. In June 2016 the New York Mets signed him as a free agent to a minor league contract. In 2016, he pitched for the Binghamton Mets of the AA Eastern League for whom he was 2–6 with a 6.32 ERA in 11 starts, and the Las Vegas 51s of the AAA Pacific Coast League for whom he was 1–0 with a 2.70 ERA. In November 2016 he elected to become a free agent. On March 28, 2017, Herron signed with the Tigres de Quintana Roo of the Mexican Baseball League. He made 12 starts, finishing with a record of 3–5 and a 5.52 ERA before he was released on June 11, 2017."Tyler Herron", milb.com He re-signed with the Fargo-Moorhead RedHawks of the American Association on June 20, 2017, for whom he was 9-3 with an ERA of 2.92."Herron Returns; Redhawks sign Pacillo" On January 30, 2018, Herron was traded to the Lincoln Saltdogs of the American Association. Pitching for them in 2018 he was 4-5 with a 7.33 ERA.Tyler Herron Minor, Winter, Independent & Mexican Leagues Statistics & History | Baseball-Reference.com On July 12, 2018, Herron was claimed off waivers by the Winnipeg Goldeyes of the American Association."Goldeyes look to stabilize pitching rotation", Winnipeg Sun. Pitching for them in 2018 he was 2-4 with a 3.19 ERA. He was released following the conclusion of the 2018 season. On May 1, 2019, Herron signed with the High Point Rockers of the Atlantic League of Professional Baseball. Pitching 17 starts for the team in 2019, he was 2-7 with a 6.05 ERA in 93.2 innings. On July 31, 2019, he was traded to the Sioux Falls Canaries of the American Association. Pitching seven starts for the team in 2019, he was 1-3 with a 3.78 ERA in 50.0 innings. Herron was released by the Canaries on February 4, 2020. However, he later re- signed with the Canaries on May 21, 2020. Herron's career minor league record through 2019 was 38–41, with a 4.12 ERA, and 588 strikeouts in 667 innings. His career foreign league record over seven seasons was 15–11 with a 3.58 ERA. And his career independent league record over eight seasons was 42–37, with a 4.03 ERA. ==World Baseball Classic; Team Israel== Herron was on the roster for Israel at the 2017 World Baseball Classic qualifier, but did not pitch."Rosters for WBC Qualifier in Brooklyn," Baseball America."Israel brings MLB experience to 1st WBC main draw", mlb.com. Herron pitched for Team Israel at the 2017 World Baseball Classic in March 2017."Israel unveils complete WBC roster; Israel will play against the host country, the Netherlands and Chinese Taipei," The Jerusalem Post, February 10, 2017. He said it was: "The best experience I've ever had in baseball for sure... It was the coolest experience I've ever had.""RedHawks starter Herron savored World Baseball Classic experience," inforum.com. ==References== ==External links== Category:1986 births Category:Living people Category:Altoona Curve players Category:American expatriate baseball players in Mexico Category:Atenienses de Manatí players Category:Baseball players from Florida Category:Binghamton Mets players Category:Caribbean Series players Category:Fargo-Moorhead RedHawks players Category:Harrisburg Senators players Category:High Point Rockers players Category:Honolulu Sharks players Category:Indios de Mayagüez players Category:Jewish American baseball players Category:Johnson City Cardinals players Category:Kalamazoo Kings players Category:Las Vegas 51s players Category:Lincoln Saltdogs players Category:Mexican League baseball pitchers Category:Palm Beach Cardinals players Category:Potomac Nationals players Category:Sioux Falls Canaries players Category:Somerset Patriots players Category:Springfield Cardinals players Category:State College Spikes players Category:Swing of the Quad Cities players Category:Syracuse Chiefs players Category:Tigres de Quintana Roo players Category:2017 World Baseball Classic players
